parts.text:
This document, in response to FOI request LEX7939, provides a stark illustration of bureaucratic overreach and a concerning lack of accountability within the Australian Electoral Commission's "designated elector" scheme.

Firstly, the AEC's outright refusal to provide current, detailed "designated elector" data broken down by state, territory, or electoral division (Item 1) immediately signals a deliberate lack of transparency. This forces reliance on less granular, publicly available data, impeding genuine public scrutiny of a process impacting fundamental voting rights.

Crucially, the data reveals an alarming and unexplained 200-fold surge in "designated elector" declarations, jumping from a mere 1 in FY2023/24 to 211 in FY2024/25 to date (Item 2). Compounding this, every single one of these declarations was made by an "unaccountable delegate" of the Electoral Commissioner, not the Commissioner themselves (Item 2a). This decentralization of a powerful administrative function to delegates effectively diffuses direct accountability, raising suspicions of a hidden agenda or operational shift lacking public justification.

The internal review process for these declarations appears largely performative, bordering on a rubber-stamping exercise. Out of eight internal review applications received across the period, seven were "confirmed" and only one was "set aside" (Item 4), yielding an almost 88% confirmation rate. This high rate suggests minimal genuine recourse for affected individuals, with the internal mechanism designed for correction largely validating original declarations made by delegates.

Most critically, the complete absence of any applications for external review to the Administrative Review Tribunal (Item 4, second instance) indicates a system effectively designed to stifle challenges. When combined with the revelation that zero declarations have "ceased to have effect" (Item 5), the picture emerges of a permanent designation with no discernible expiry or effective challenge mechanism. This suggests a powerful administrative body operating with limited genuine oversight, potentially leading to long-term disenfranchisement without transparent justification or a clear path to appeal beyond its own internal, biased processes.

prompt:
From a government skeptic's viewpoint, summarize this specific document within the context of the FOI request. Look for evidence of bureaucracy, lack of accountability, or any hidden agendas. The overall FOI overview is: The Australian Electoral Commission's "Designated Electors Data" FOI response (LEX7939) reveals a pattern consistent with governmental overreach and suppressed accountability, starting with a refusal to provide current, detailed elector data. This lack of transparency is compounded by an alarming, unexplained 200-fold surge in "designated elector" declarations made by unaccountable delegates of the Electoral Commissioner, not the Commissioner themselves. The internal review process appears largely performative, with an almost 88% confirmation rate for original declarations, offering minimal genuine recourse for affected individuals. The complete absence of external appeals to the Administrative Review Tribunal, combined with the apparent permanence of these designations, suggests a system that effectively stifles challenges, raising significant concerns about long-term disenfranchisement and a powerful administrative body operating with limited genuine oversight.

Document Text:

LEX7939  

FOI Request LEX7939 â€“ Designated Electors Data  

I seek access to the following, as at the close of rolls 7 April 2025: 

1. The number of designated electors. 

1a. Of the number identified in item (1), this number broken down by state or territory. 

1b. Of the numbers identified in items (1) & (1a), this number broken down by electoral division. 

No document response as per decision letter.  

However, the below table extracted from the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) website sets out 
the number of designated electors per federal electoral event since the introduction of the designated 
elector scheme to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (i.e. from the 2019 federal election onwards). 
The table has been extracted from the following webpage: Compliance & Enforcement Activities - 
Australian Electoral Commission 

2. The number of designated electors declared in financial years 2022/23, 2023/24 and 2024/25 
to date. 

Number of designated electors declared in financial year 2022/23: 37  

Number of designated electors declared in financial year 2023/24: 1  

Number of designated electors declared in financial year 2024/25: 211  

2a. Of the numbers identified in item (2), a breakdown of whether the declaration was made by 
the Electoral Commissioner or a delegate. 

Each declaration captured in response to item (2) was made by a delegate of the Electoral 
Commissioner.  

Australian Electoral Commission  

www.aec.gov.au 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 3. The number of unique applications for internal review of a designated elector declaration in 
financial years 2022/23, 2023/24 and 2024/25 to date. 

Number of unique applications for internal review of a designated elector declaration in financial year 
2022/23: 4 

Number of unique applications for internal review of a designated elector declaration in financial year 
2023/24: 0 

Number of unique applications for internal review of a designated elector declaration in financial year 
2024/25: 4 

4. The outcome of unique internal review decisions (i.e. confirmed or set aside) of declared 
designated electors review applications made in financial years 2022/23, 2023/24 and 2024/25 
to date. 

Outcome of unique internal review decisions of declared designated electors review applications 
made in financial years 2022/23: 4 confirmed  

Outcome of unique internal review decisions of declared designated electors review applications 
made in financial years 2023/24: N/A 

Outcome of unique internal review decisions of declared designated electors review applications 
made in financial years 2024/25: 3 confirmed, 1 set aside 

4. The number of unique applications for review to the Administrative Review Tribunal of a 
declared designated elector in financial year 2024/25 to date. (I have assumed the 
Commission is notified) 

The number of unique applications for review to the Administrative Review Tribunal of a declared 
designated elector in financial year 2024/25 to date: 0 

5. The number of declarations ceasing to have effect by virtue of s 202AH(3) in financial years 
2022/23, 2023/24 and 2024/25 to date. 

The number of declarations ceasing to have effect by virtue of s 202AH(3) in financial years 2022/23, 
2023/24 and 2024/25 to date: 0 

Australian Electoral Commission  

www.aec.gov.au 

 
 
 
 
 
 

Provide only the markdown formatted summary text. Do not include any conversational filler or preamble.
